head.title: SPARE TIMES: April 20 - April 26; For Children

hedline.hl1: SPARE TIMES: April 20 - April 26; For Children

block.p: AUDRAROX (Sunday) One way to get children to listen to parents: Put Mom and Dad in a rock band. Most members of AudraRox, playing an Earth Day concert for ages 2 to 7, have children themselves. At 11:30 a.m., the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3337, thejewishmuseum.org. Tickets: $15; $10 for under 12; $12 and $8 for family-level members.

TOM CHAPIN (Tomorrow) Who better to perform a musical salute to Earth Day than a composer and musician who recorded a CD entitled ''This Pretty Planet''? At 11 a.m., Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400; symphonyspace.org. Tickets in advance: $23 and $18; $13 for 12 and under. Day of show: $25 and $20; $13 for 12 and under. Members: $19 and $14; members of Just Kidding Club, $8.

'CINDERELLA' (Tomorrow and Sunday) This hourlong ''Cinderella'' by New York Theater Ballet is lighthearted, with stepsisters (men in drag) who are more buffoonish than cruel. (Through April 29.) At 11 a.m. and 1 and 3:30 p.m., Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (212) 355-6160; $30; $25 for 12 and under.

EARTH DAY EGGSTRAVAGANZA (Tomorrow and Sunday) Three-quarters of the earth is covered by water, and the South Street Seaport will salute its inhabitants on the tall ship Peking, where children will learn about sea turtles and other species. From noon to 5 p.m., Pier 16, South Street and the East River, Lower Manhattan, (212) 748-8753; $5 (does not include museum admission).

EARTH DAY WEEKEND AT THE ZOOS (Tomorrow and Sunday) Conserving the environment also means conserving earth's creatures. At the Bronx Zoo's Earth Day Party, from 11 a.m. through 4:30 p.m., visitors can follow the Path for Planet Earth, on which they can go on a poetry safari (to write and hear wild and wooly verse) and see demonstrations with the zoo's tigers. (Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road, Fordham, 718-367-1010, bronxzoo.com. Free with admission: $14; $12 for 65+; $10 for 3 to 12; free for under 3.) Three other zoos are celebrating from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.: Polar bears are the focus at the Central Park Zoo, where children can play ecological bingo. (Fifth Avenue and 64th Street, 212-439-6500, centralparkzoo.com.) Baboons are big at the Prospect Park Zoo, which will hold a baboon scavenger hunt and zookeeper chats. (450 Flatbush Avenue, Prospect Park, Brooklyn, 718-399-7339, prospectparkzoo.com.) The Queens Zoo has planned animal crafts, a treasure hunt and appropriate storytelling: Dr. Seuss's book ''The Lorax.'' (53-51 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, 718-271-1500, queenszoo.com). All free with admission: $6; $2.25 for 65+; $2 for 3 to 12; free for under 3. The Staten Island Zoo has its own fair, with animal feedings, keeper talks and a new reptile wing. (614 Broadway, West Brighton, 718-442-3100, statenislandzoo.org; $7; $5 for 65+; $4 for 3 through 14; under 3, free.)

'THE GAME BOY' (Tomorrow and Sunday) This musical from Vital Children's Theater is about a fourth grader, Chase, who is so wrapped up in his new video game that he starts to neglect the real world. Sound familiar? At 11 a.m. and 1 p.m., the McGinn/Cazale Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street, fourth floor, (212) 352-3101; $18.

IMMIGRANT HISTORY WEEK Shows (Tomorrow and Sunday) The city is saluting its melting pot with performances at Queens Library branches. They include the Hypothetical Theater Company's ''Ellis Island Stories,'' a one-act play, tomorrow at 3 p.m. at the Forest Hills branch, 108-19 71 Avenue, (718) 268-7934. On Sunday there's the ''Russian Festival: From Odessa to St. Petersburg,'' with immigrant artists, at the Flushing branch, 41-17 Main Street, (718) 990-0891. Free.

THE JCC IN MANHATTAN (Tomorrow and Sunday) An independent princess, an intrepid immigrant girl and those enthusiastic students from Disney's ''High School Musical'' take the stage. Tomorrow Jennifer Levine offers the puppet shows ''Princess Moxie Rules'' (2:30 p.m.), for ages 3 to 7, and ''Miracle on Monroe Street'' (3:30 p.m.), for 8 and older. Both free. On Sunday Sasha Nanus directs the New York Teen Theater in ''High School Musical.'' (Through April 29.) Tomorrow at 8:30 p.m., Sunday at noon and 3 p.m., Wednesday at 5 p.m; $10 and $12; students, $7 and $8. At 334 Amsterdam Avenue, at 76th Street. Reservations for all shows: (646) 505-5708.

'MACBETH' (Tonight through Sunday, and Thursday) Is that a dagger I see before me? No, it's a puppet. Well, a dagger-wielding puppet. In this abridged adaptation, presented by Chicago Shakespeare Company and Colla Marionette Company of Italy, the players are three feet tall and on strings. But it's still ''Macbeth,'' recommended for children 12 and older. Tonight at 7, tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m., Sunday at noon and 5 p.m., New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200; $12.50, $25 and $35.

NATIONAL AND GLOBAL YOUTH SERVICE DAY (Tomorrow) Children for Children, a nonprofit organization, will honor this day of volunteering with service projects administered from two locations in Hudson River Park in Manhattan: Pier 46, at Christopher Street, West Village, and Pier 84, at 42nd Street. Free; (212) 850-4170.

'OTHER WORDS/OTHER WORLDS' JAZZ AND POETRY MARATHON (Tomorrow) This daylong celebration includes ''Jazzy Storytelling'' (10 a.m. to noon); a poetry workshop for children and parents (noon to 1 p.m.); and performances by high school jazz ensembles and poets. The event runs to 10 p.m., with many open-mike opportunities. At Flushing Town Hall, 137-35 Northern Boulevard, Queens, (718) 463-7700, Ext. 222, flushingtownhall.org. From 10 a.m. to noon, $8; $2 for 12 and under; $4 and $2 for members. Afternoon, free.

PERCUSSION PEOPLE (Sunday) Instrument building is on the menu at the interactive monthly concerts presented by this group, which explores the range of percussion instruments across cultures. Young drumming enthusiasts (what child isn't one?) are encouraged to arrive at 10:30 a.m. and make their own instruments for the concert at 11. At the Players Theater, 115 Macdougal Street, near West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 352-3101; $15.

EMILIE SIMON: 'LA MARCHE DE L'EMPEREUR' ('THE MARCH OF THE PENGUINS') (Sunday) Even if you've seen ''The March of the Penguins,'' you probably haven't heard this version: Joe's Pub is screening the documentary with the French composer Emilie Simon's original soundtrack, not in the American release. (The screening is in English.) Ms. Simon will perform solo sets before and after. At 11 a.m., the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555; $15; $10 for under 12. Table reservations: (212) 539-8778; $12 minimum.

'SLEEPING BEAUTY' (Sunday) The Bronx Arts Ensemble and the Lehman Children's Theater Company will wake up any slumbering audience members with a slapstick version, including an introduction to wind instruments. At 2 p.m., the Riverdale Y, 5625 Arlington Avenue, at West 256th Street, the Bronx (718) 601-7399; $7.

THEATREWORKS/USA (Tomorrow and Sunday) Casey Carle is forever blowing bubbles, but his are more extraordinary than most: six-foot spheres, cubes, even a spacecraft. He will show them off tomorrow in ''Bubblemania,'' while on Sunday Rebecca Frezza and Big Truck perform a concert salute to childhood. Both days at 10:30 a.m., the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 279-4200; $25.

'TRA LA LA -- CAPTAIN UNDERPANTS EXTRAVAGAnza' (Tomorrow) Fans of Dav Pilkey and his books about Captain Underpants, that stern principal turned superhero in briefs, can revel in this tribute, which includes food, crafts and games. At 3:30 p.m., Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 621-0618, nypl.org; free.
